content: Bruh, this is tough. I gotta pick between 4, and each one is important in a different way. 3D modeling with Blender is the ultimate form of creativity and self-expression, but I struggle to spend enough time with it. LEGO design is where I feel most at home, and I judge all other hobbies by the emotional reward I get from LEGO. It's my oldest hobby so it makes sense. Then there’s game design; I got into it because another friend of mine designed games as well, and together we created about 10 or something through high school. And lastly, DANCE. Don't ask me to describe what I do and expect a straightforward answer with dance. No current labels fit it well, because all forms of dancing styles are not what I do. Mine's a freestyle, hip-hop illusion, feel-the-beat, freaking song-loving style that comes most alive when I feel a song the most. Not dubstep music or music designed for dance, because that music is extremely stupid. But music that is songs for real, on God. Like, when a song is created from someone's heart that is designed to touch others' souls in a specific way, and I am touched in that way, my dancing reflects that song and how in the zone I am. Unfortunately, you may never see me dance until someone sponsors a world tour or something. But that's okay because that part of me is my personal proof I have a soul and a personality—it's not for everyone else to see.

There is no usual way. Other than anxious and working, I hope to have a good time with some friends at least one of the weekend days. If I don't though, I guess right now I'm trying to advance my career by staying on top of building good habits for the future. College life be takin' over my whole being.

Nah, don't have one. I can tell you I like the restaurant 54th Street, I like natural lemonade from Sonic, and I need more people to enjoy the restaurant Cracker Barrel. PEOPLE DO NOT BE FOOLED BY ITS RUSTIC DESIGN. IT'S AN AMAZING ESTABLISHMENT YOU MUST GO THERE.

Another freaking question I can't answer like you want. I'm not upset at the question; rather, I understand that it's upsetting to losers who want a straight answer. Like, where do y'all get off asking straightforward questions and then expecting straightforward answers? Anyway, I don't like all kinds of music, but I also don't dislike a kind of music either. To explain: I don't like death metal. But I also don't have a few genres I like because many things in those genres are trash. I noticed a lot of other people in the world can enjoy banger songs like me, but also songs that are genuine filth because it's in a genre they like. Highlights: Noah Kahan, Maroon 5, Michael Jackson, JP Saxe, Pentatonix, Half Alive, Sam Fender, Jon Bellion, Katie Lynne Sharbaugh, and I'll stop there because there are so many others, but like I can't just—24kGoldn, Lil Nas X, Remi Wolf, Paramore, Dominic Fike—okay-okay-okay-that's it... that's all of them—5SOS, Madcon, Home Free, Adele, SEAL, MAX. Okay, I'm exhausted. I'm exhausted. There is probably more, but I'm tired.

This is a great question with an easy answer. We will start with honorable mentions: Community, The Office, the first 10 years of MCU, and many more inspiring things. But the number one movie of all time is 'The LEGO Batman Movie.' It has comedy, sound design, and rich detailed LEGO design. I mean, you already are having to animate a whole movie. The fact that they also designed the things out of LEGO is a second part of the process, are you kidding me? Perfect humor, perfect dual personification of LEGO and Batman. They created a line of toys that accompany the movie. I could go on. My favorite show that isn't a sitcom: Moon Knight. Probably the most famous fact about me among those close. ('Welcome to the closeness club... sorry that it sounds so weird.') It's so famous because the show is not well watched, the character is not well known, and because of that people do not understand why I could enjoy it. It makes me rather sad that the show goes unnoticed for its unparalleled ability to stick to an unwavering aesthetic that is challenged by no other show. It consistently hits in all elements of lighting, set design, focusing and shot angles, and attention to detail related to Steven/Mark character, Moon Knight as a character, and the Egyptian element to his powers. They also created the first truly fresh story for a superhero in over 10 years. The show was written to be separate from the MCU, so it was very focused on its own thing and its own universe and rules, and you can feel that attention paid. The acting for a story about a troubled man trying to do his best, working alongside his patron god who is perhaps twisted in his own way, is an amazing way to bring attention to mental health and how someone can overcome things to do their best for the world. An unrecognized hero who will still do what he can for others while his life has continuously fallen apart. Played out masterfully with 6 episodes, some with cliffhangers, some with satisfying endings. It is an effort of mine for people to give this irregular story a chance, as its values are not that of just a superhero show, but far beyond, honestly.My favorite sitcom is New Girl. I don't want to hear a fight. If you don't agree, you are crazy. I mean mental, your priorities aren't straight, you are probably hurt deep down. You need help. Call someone. The most important thing about a show and a sitcom is characters. The most important thing to creating something for a screen in my opinion, but especially for a sitcom, is not telling a story through characters, but telling characters through story. It is essential to not get focused on plot, but to have the plot focused on them. This show has the greatest dynamic of characters that do an amazing job of being crazy and stupid where a sitcom demands, but still being generally down to earth, which is where other sitcoms don't have a similar balance because they often have a less equal mixing of sanity across the cast. The humor in this show is top-notch, and it shows some truth about life in a way that makes you appreciate the world more.
Spikeball, pickleball, volleyball, tossing the Aerobie rings, and ultimate frisbee. I don’t follow sports though, it doesn’t make sense to me.

I guess the answer to this question would be clear in the order in which like 20 thoughts just flooded to my head in order. Answering this question revealed to me how in touch I am with what I value, and I appreciate that. I don't have a favorite memory per se, but perhaps a favorite place, era, or mix of a few different moments. When I was around 12, my best friend's house was probably my favorite place to be. I was there often, and I feel like it forged me and my values, and I deeply appreciate it. That era of my life may even be my favorite, but when I started going to private school, I had some good times. Most notable were many occasions of creating and playing board games with friends in high school.
Rom-com books, man. All day. Please, give me some more.

Any superpower? How many times have I been asked this, and forgotten my answer. Then I had to think of it again later. Best superpower ever would be to remember this freaking answer. But, uh, I guess my answer would be something I invented when I was a child. I liked to design superhero characters, and I had a guy who could turn his body into elements or mixtures of elements. I called him Mr. Material :'{. Very good childhood memory. But, uh, yeah, I imagined he would look cool, and he would also be able to transform elements around him into elements of choice temporarily. If not, I would want the powers of Green Lantern, because being able to create whatever you imagine is amazing.
I’m not getting stranded on an island. But if I had to choose: my three best friends. Losers will say 'a knife, water filter, and fire starter'. Nah. that's for suckers who want to survive.

I’ve always wanted to learn 3D design and music production—3D design is already in progress. I’d also love to understand deeper levels of programming, even if it’s not my favorite thing to learn. Also, making AI—huge goal for me.
Not gonna happen. Refer to my answer about comfort foods.

I have a sister. For some reason, this SHOCKS people. Like, why is that so surprising? People pass out, they GASP, and pass out (jk). Maybe they’re amazed someone could survive living with me for so long. Ha.
I don’t care about history enough to have a good answer for this, man.
If life is stress-free, then dance, Marvel Snap, and 3D design. If I can hang out with friends, even better.
I’d figure out how much I could give to others in a way that maximizes benefits for them. Then, I’d take a chunk to professionally make and sell some of my board and card games.
I don’t have an adventure story to tell, but I wish I did.
Amazing question, my god. Definitely the Phineas and Ferb universe—happiest universe to be in, hands down.
Any country, any country at all. Wherever has the best theme park, but only if my friends can go with me. Otherwise, I don't care.

It's a mixture of two things. Firstly, my motivation is to prove to myself that I can accomplish whatever it is. And secondly, to make other people's lives better by getting to the other side of whatever my obstacle is. I feel guilty about people who have suffered much more but have also done more with their life. So I want to channel that unhealthy guilt into healthy behaviors of staying strong through tough things and not complaining.

Failure is a constant part of life. I would say the negative way I handle failure is the obsession mid-fail—how absolutely obsessed I become with doing something and not failing it, even if I don't get it figured out. I usually handle all things post-failure with clarity and peace, as I recognize where to grow from and that it is a part of life. Sometimes, I get motivated to do better or try again.

I believe that the most important thing in life is relationships. Sorry to get so deep with such a question, but I don't want to answer it another way. Some people may answer this in a silly way, saying something like 'this random freaking video game from 2000 is literally the greatest game of all...' Not me. My answer is this because I have found, to my surprise, that other people on this planet do not agree. They think other things are more valuable than relationships. Often because of their religious beliefs. But even so, in those religions, they should still value relationships above all if not second. The key principle is that you need to not strive for anything in life until you have a good social situation figured out first. You have nothing, and nothing you do will have value if it isn't for other people and for those in your life. Do everything you do to give back to those in your life and enjoy life with them. Life is short, and afterlife is a mystery.
Talk less.

I have made several mistakes that are all the same mistake. I can get into a process where I'm trying to solve a problem, and I get obsessed and chaotic. I go from one task to another without truly finishing anything. This can even cause me to get really close to the solution but get sidetracked at the last second. Others have observed this about me and how it affected me or their work life and gave me advice. Now I take time to do one thing at a time and see a process through, and it has greatly increased patience and efficiency.

I am a spaceship lover, so I am always wanting to build a spaceship. Usually, my inspiration comes from three things: either a color scheme, some new pieces, or completely out of the blue. Sometimes, I see a color scheme I like, or LEGO introduces a new color, and I want to make something out of it. Sometimes, LEGO introduces a new piece, and I want to incorporate it into something sci-fi, transforming it into a new version of itself. Sometimes, I am just in the mood to build something, and pure inspiration takes hold of me and starts building.

I enjoy solving problems in the game design process and making a mechanic for a game that will have the largest impact on fun. I love when I am brainstorming, and I solve an issue with some of the mechanics, and that solution is also the best part of the game itself.

I don't know what the game would be about, like a theme or anything. But I definitely want it to be online multiplayer because that is the best game experience in my opinion. I want it to be a mix of strategy and randomness. I want teams or individuals to have many moments of playing the odds and playing the opponent. I think a game that is pure strategy isn't enough fun. It's all about having a good time with others. Honestly, I would like to make one of my games into a video game, although it would just be transforming a board game into a video game.

My process is currently to get better at the process. It's a lot of trying things and seeing what works, but it's also just about getting better at modeling. I like to create things from scratch, not replicate real-world things, so it's all based on the spur of the moment. But you always have to be smart and make backups and keep your environments clean. Also, set timers and don't let yourself burn out.

I did a 3D design of a 12-sided die for a game. It came out looking really good, and it was a project that took a long time with many troubleshooting processes. There wasn't a straightforward tutorial online, so I pioneered and engineered a lot of the things I needed to happen.

Plot-driven movies or shows are a failure to mankind. They totally have no value when the story is not about the characters but is about what happens to people. That's why I am oftentimes not a fan of anime, many Netflix originals, and things like that. They are just something to watch with an overarching plot; they aren't about the people and making good characters that are entertaining in and of themselves.

I think that we need to be careful to make sure AI doesn't get used to harm other people. That's our biggest concern—security. But my hot take on artificial intelligence is that I think we should try and create the smartest, most sentient life form we can with AI. I think we should try and make something so human it's even a step above human. I think we should essentially try and create the next form of intelligence.
Make others laugh.
Someone makes a joke that is incredibly creative and entirely situational. Someone pulls the trigger on a joke that only makes sense in the moment—I feel the most alive in those moments.
Woah woah woah. You aren't getting the answer to that question.

If I swap lives and I make it out alive, probably someone suffering somewhere. Maybe a woman in a foreign country that doesn't respect her rights. Give her a day of freedom, and let me understand how others are living better—maybe it will inspire me to do something about it.
I can snap coins and playing cards across rooms and hit things that I want, just with the snap of my fingers.
If I want to kill them or hear them out. And for the record, I would hear them out.

I bought myself some Meta Ray-Ban glasses because my self-care needs to include a good routine. I love having no game plan in the day; it's freeing, but that can also cause me to struggle or feel overwhelmed. The glasses allow me to set reminders and designate tasks for different days or hours of the day. Along with that, I have found other ways to keep track of my thoughts so I become less overwhelmed that my thoughts disappear into nothing and I will get nothing done.
Other people, humor, becoming better than I think I can be.

Working in teams with people that are smarter or dumber than me, it doesn't matter. When I'm brainstorming as a team or feel the support of a good team, I become superhuman in all of the areas I contribute to the goal. Give me a team, and it unlocks all my hidden stats.

I feel strong emotionally often after I feel weak emotionally. That is because I recognize the depth of how I'm feeling or what I'm thinking about, and find comfort that I'm even processing these levels of things and enjoying comforts living in a place like America. Sometimes growth from the lows brings highs because it shows you what you are able to feel emotionally.
I don't have a system of recharging because I never lose charge.
That I have time, space, and comfort living in America during modern times. At the end of the day, most of my issues are small.
Realizing I need to do better.
What are some ways you take time for yourself?
I do that so often it's not even a struggle. You gotta take time for yourself, man; it's the most important thing. If you don't have time to do things for you, who even are you? You have to rest.
Letting go of annoying things and letting things pass for a day, re-approaching it later.
